content.html:
Matthew had a problem. His Aunt Tina was visiting that afternoon, and he had nothing for her to eat!

“I could buy some cake!” Matthew thought. He had passed a bakery earlier that day which had a very yummy-looking coconut cake in the window. That would be perfect!

Matthew ek problem mein pad gaya tha. Tina Aunty dopahar mein usse milne ane wali thi and uske paas unhe khilane ke liye kuch bhi nahi tha!

"Hm, mein thoda cake khareed ke la sakta hun" Matthew ne socha. Wah thodi der pehle ek bakery se hota hua nikla tha jahan usne ek window mein bohot hi tasty coconut cake dekha tha. Ye cake uske liya perfect hoga!

hint_content.html: Start by finding the denominator. The denominator is the total number of equal parts that the whole cake is divided into.

Next, find the numerator by counting the number of selected parts.

In this case, it's the number of parts that have mangoes (the orange pieces) on them. Make sure to count carefully!

Always be careful about what you're counting. The question will have clues!

Here, we're looking at a fraction of the cake. So, we should be counting pieces of the cake, not the individual fruits.

content.html:
Meet Matthew!

Matthew is a young man who likes friends, sports, and eating cake! He also likes learning new things. We’ll follow Matthew as he learns about fractions and how to use them.

You should know the following before going on:

  • The counting numbers (1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ….)
  • How to tell whether one counting number is bigger or smaller than another

You should also get some paper and a pen or pencil to write with, and find a quiet place to work. Take your time, and go through the story at your own pace. Understanding is more important than speed!

Once you’re ready, click Continue to get started!

es.html:
Conoce a Mateo!

 

Mateo es un joven a quien le gustan los amigos, los deportes y comer pastel! También le gusta aprender cosas nuevas. Seguiremos a Mateo a medida que aprende sobre las fracciones y cómo usarlas.

Debes saber lo siguiente antes de continuar:

  • Los números de conteo (1, 2, 3, 4, 5….)
  • Cómo saber si un número de conteo es mayor o menor que otro

También debe obtener papel y un bolígrafo o lápiz para escribir, y encontrar un lugar tranquilo para trabajar. Tómate tu tiempo y recorre la historia a tu propio ritmo. ¡La comprensión es más importante que la velocidad!

Una vez que estés listo, haz clic en Continuar para comenzar.

hi-en.html:
Matthew ek jawaan ladka hai jise dost, sports or cake khana bohot pasand hai. Usse nayi cheeze seekhne mein bhi bada maza ata hai. Hum dekhenge ki Matthew kaise fractions ke baare mein seekhte hai aur kaise uska use karte hai.

Agey badne se pehle, aap ye dhyaan rakhe ki aapko neeche di gayi cheeze pata ho:

1. Numbers count karna (1, 2, 3...)

2. Yeh batana ki 2 numbers mein se kaunsa number bada hai

Aap ek pencil ya pen aur ek paper apne saath rakh le aur ek shaant jagah dhoond le jahan aap araam se kaam kar sake. Aap is exploration ko complete karne ke liye jitna time chahte hai, utna le sakte hai. Is exploration ko ache se samjhna is more important than ise jaldi se khatam karna.

Jab aap ready ho, tab Continue par click kare!

content.html:
Taking his coconut cake with him, Matthew triumphantly headed home to Aunt Tina. He was already planning to have friends over the next afternoon, so he knew he’d be back to the bakery for more goodies soon!

Before leaving the bakery, Matthew wrote down some important notes in his notebook. Write them down, so that you remember too!

  • Fractions describe parts of a whole. They can be written using a slash, e.g. 2/3.
  • The number on the left is called the numerator. It is the number of selected pieces.
  • The number on the right is called the denominator. It is the total number of equal pieces that the whole is divided into.

hi-en.html:
Matthew Tina aunty ke liye apne saath coconut cake lekar ghar chal diya. Wo agle din apne kuch friends ko ghar par bulane ka plan banane wala tha, isliye usse pata tha ki use jald hi firse bakery ana hoga.

Bakery se niklane se pehle, Matthew ne apni notebook mein kuch important cheeze likhi. Aap bhi inhe apni notebook mein likh sakte hai jisse ye apko yaad rahe.

  • Fraction kisi pure cheez ke parts ko describe karta hai. Hum unhe ek forward-slash ya ek horizontal bar ke saath likh sakhte hai.
  • Fraction ka first part numerator kehlata hai. Ye batata hai ki humne kitne pieces select kiye hai.
  • Dusra part denominator kehlata hai. Ye batata hai ki humne puri cheej ko kitne parts mein divide kiya hai.

es.html:
Llevando el pastel de coco con él, Mateo se dirigió triunfalmente a casa con la tía Tina. Ya estaba planeando invitar amigos la tarde siguiente, ¡así que sabía que volvería a la panadería para más cosas pronto!

Antes de dejar la panadería, Mateo escribió algunas notas importantes en su cuaderno. ¡Anótalos, para que los recuerdes también!

  • Las fracciones describen partes de un todo. Se pueden escribir utilizando una barra o una barra horizontal, por ejemplo. 2/3.
  • El número de la izquierda (o superior) se llama numerador. Es el número de piezas seleccionadas.
  • El número a la derecha (o abajo) se llama denominador. Es el número total de piezas iguales en que se divide el todo.

hint_content.html:
When you divide something into five equal parts, each part is called a fifth.



How many fifths are in the last picture that Mr. Baker drew?

content.html:
Matthew looked confused. "What's a fraction?" he asked.

"Ah," said Mr. Baker. "That just means how much of the whole thing you want.” He picked up a napkin and a pencil. “Look,” he said, starting to draw.

“Here’s a cake. Pretend it’s divided into five equal parts, OK? Since there are five equal parts, each part is called a fifth.”

Then he picked up a colored pencil and colored in one of the parts.

“Now look, Matthew. If I asked you how many parts of the cake were colored red, we could say one fifth. Because one of the fifths is colored in.”

Then he colored in another piece.

“Now, two fifths of the cake are red. Both ‘one fifth’ and ‘two fifths’ are fractions, because they tell us how much of a whole thing we’re talking about.

“Now here’s an easy question for you,” said Mr. Baker, coloring another part of the cake. "Look at the picture below. How many fifths are colored red now?"

es.html:
Mateo parecía confundido. "¿Qué es una fracción?" preguntó.

"Ah", dijo el Sr. Baker. "Eso significa cuánto de todo el pastel quieres". Tomó una servilleta y un lápiz. "Mira", dijo, empezando a dibujar.


"Aquí hay un pastel. Imagina que está dividido en cinco partes iguales, ¿vale? Como hay cinco partes iguales, cada parte se llama una quinta ".

Luego tomó un lápiz de color y coloreo en una de las partes.


"Ahora mira, Mateo. Si te preguntara cuántas partes de la torta tenían un color rojo, podríamos decir una quinta parte. Porque una de las quintas está coloreada ".

Luego él coloreo en otra pieza.


“Ahora, las dos quintas partes del pastel son rojas. Tanto "una quinta parte" como "dos quintas partes" son fracciones, porque nos dicen de qué cosa estamos hablando.

"Ahora, esta es una pregunta fácil para ti, dijo el Sr. Baker, coloreando otra parte del pastel. "Mira la imagen de abajo. ¿Cuántas quintas están en rojo ahora?"

hi-en.html:
Matthew confuse ho gaya - "Fraction kya hota hai?" - usne poocha.

"Ah", Mr Baker ne kaha - "Uska matlab hota hai ki aap pure cake mein se kitna cake chahte hai". Unhone ek napkin aur pencil uthake kaha "Dekhiye" aur fir wo napkin pe kuch draw karne lage.

"Ye hai ek cake. Ab maan lijiye ise humne 5 equal parts mein divide kar diya hai, theek hai? Kyonki is cake ke 5 equal parts hai, hum har part ko one-fifth bulate hai".

Fir ek color pencil se unhone cake ke ek part ko color kar diya.

"Ab dekhiye, Matthew. Agar mein aapse yeh poochun ki cake ke kitne parts colored hai, tab aap keh sakte hai one-fifth. Because sare 5 parts mein se ek part colored hai".

Fir unhone ne ek aur part color kar diya.

As Matthew entered the bakery, a kind-looking man looked up from the counter and smiled at him.

"Hello!" he said. "My name’s Mr. Baker. What would you like today?"

"The coconut cake in the window!" Matthew answered.

“The whole cake?" asked Mr. Baker.

"Ummmm.... no," said Matthew. He knew how to ask for one, or two, or three cakes. But he didn’t want the whole cake. He just wanted part of it.

“You know,” Mr. Baker said kindly. “I can cut a small piece for you, if you like. Just tell me how much. What fraction of the cake would you like?”

hint_content.html:
Here is the important part of Mr. Baker's explanation of how to write a fraction:

  • The first number tells us how many parts we want.
  • The second number tells us the total number of equal parts.

Can you use this to answer the question?
What is the total number of equal parts that the whole cake is divided into? That should be the second number in the fraction.

The whole cake is divided into 7 equal parts, so 7 is the second number in the fraction.

So, the fraction must be: ?/7. Can you figure out the first number?

content.html:
“That’s correct!" said Mr. Baker. "You see, a fraction tells us two things: how many parts we want, and the type of each of the parts.

"It’s quicker to use numbers rather than words to write fractions. So, instead of writing 'two fifths', we can write 2/5':

  • The first number tells us how many parts we want. For example, if the first number is 2, that means we want 2 parts.
  • The second number tells us the total number of equal parts, so that we know how large each part is. For example, if the second number is 5, that means the whole picture is divided into 5 equal parts.

"Here's another example. Look carefully at the following picture:

"This picture is divided into six equal parts, so our fraction looks like ?/6. Four of the parts are yellow, so the fraction of the circle that is yellow is 4/6.

"Now, take a look at this cake."

"Which of these fractions describes the darker part of the cake?"

  • El primer número nos dice cuántas partes queremos. Por ejemplo, si el primer número es 2, eso significa que queremos 2 partes.

  • El segundo número nos dice el número total de partes iguales, para que sepamos qué tan grande es cada parte. Por ejemplo, si el segundo número es 5, eso significa que la imagen completa se divide en 5 partes iguales.

"Esta imagen se divide en seis partes iguales, por lo que nuestra fracción parece ?/6. Cuatro de las partes son amarillas, por lo que la fracción del círculo que es amarillo es 4/6

Congratulations on completing this lesson! We hope you found it to be … a piece of cake!

Matthew had learned from Mr. Baker what a fraction was. But there was one thing he wondered about: why did Mr. Baker keep talking about "equal parts", not just "parts"? Was it important that the parts were equal?

To find out, take a look at the next lesson, where Matthew meets Crumb, the Assistant Baker, for the first time!

hint_content.html: To do this question, you'll need to count very carefully. Double-check your work, and use a pencil and paper to take notes if you need to.
The denominator of the fraction is the total number of pieces of cake.
There are 12 pieces of cake, so the denominator is 12.

The numerator is trickier. We want to know what fraction of the cake "has chocolate chips AND mangoes, but NOT cherries”. 

So, we need to count the number of pieces that have chocolate chips and mangoes (the orange pieces), but not cherries. That gives us the numerator.
Which pieces only have orange fruits and black dots, but no red fruits? There are exactly 5 of them. So the numerator is 5.

"Let's make sure you know how to write a fraction," said Mr. Baker. "Take your time to understand this carefully, and don't rush. Otherwise, we'll need to keep looking at this again."

"Now," said Mr. Baker, "when writing a fraction, we need to remember two things:

  • The first number tells us how many parts are selected.
  • The second number tells us the total number of equal parts, so that we know how large each part is. This always includes all the parts, both the ones that are selected, and the ones that aren't selected.

  • El primer número nos dice cuántas partes están seleccionadas.

  • El segundo número nos dice el número total de partes iguales, para que sepamos qué tan grande es cada parte. Esto siempre incluye todas las partes, tanto las que están seleccionadas como las que no están seleccionadas.

content.html:
"Now," said Mr. Baker, "to properly talk about fractions, there are two words you need to know: numerator and denominator.

"The numerator is always the first or top number, the number of parts we want. For example, in 1/6, the numerator is 1. And, in 3/4, the numerator is 3.

"The denominator is always the second or bottom number, the total number of equal parts. For example, in 1/6, the denominator is 6. And, in 3/4, the denominator is 4.

"Here's another example: in 2/5, the numerator is 2, and the denominator is 5.

                                   ------------------------------------------------

"Now, Matthew," said Mr. Baker, "here's a question for you. In 2/8, what is the denominator?"

es.html:
"Ahora", dijo el Sr. Baker, para hablar correctamente sobre las fracciones, hay dos palabras que debe saber: numerador y denominador.

"El numerador es siempre el primer número o el número superior, el número de partes que queremos. Por ejemplo, en 1/6, el numerador es 1. Y, en 3/4, el numerador es 3.

"El denominador es siempre el segundo o el número de abajo, el número total de partes iguales. Por ejemplo, en 1/6, el denominador es 6. Y, en 3/4, el denominador es 4.

"Aquí hay otro ejemplo: en 2/5, el numerador es 2 y el denominador es 5.

 

"Ahora, Mateo", dijo el Sr. Baker, "aquí hay una pregunta para ti. En 2/8, ¿cuál es el denominador?"

"Fractions ke bare mein apko 2 cheeje pata honi chahiye: numerator aur denominator"

Denominator humesha second ya neeche wala number hota hai jo hume batata hai ki humne ek cheej ko kitne equal parts mein cut kiya hai. For example, agar fraction 1/6 hai toh numerator 1 hai aur denominator 6 hai"

"Ye raha apke liye ek sawaal: 2/8 mein, denominator kya hai?"
